instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: What is the purpose of the UtilityCost:Charge:Block object?
output: The UtilityCost:Charge:Block objects are used extensively for tariff calculation to compute energy and demand charges structured in blocks of charges and may also be used for taxes surcharges and other utility bill charges.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: What is more commonly used for simple flat charges?
output: UtilityCost:Charge:Simple is more commonly used for simple flat charges.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: How many UtilityCost:Charge:Block objects can be defined for a single tariff?
output: As many UtilityCost:Charge:Block objects as needed may be defined for a single tariff and they will be added together.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: Why are blocks used by utilities in calculating charges?
output: Blocks are used by utilities to charge more or less per unit of energy or demand if more units are used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> Field: Charge Variable Name -> text
input: What is the significance of the Charge Variable Name field?
output: The Charge Variable Name field is the name associated with the UtilityCost:Charge:Block object appears in the report and stores the results in a variable with the same name for further calculations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> Field: Tariff Name -> text
input: What does the Tariff Name field specify?
output: The Tariff Name field specifies the name of the tariff associated with the UtilityCost:Charge:Block.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> Field: Source Variable -> text
input: What is typically the Source Variable in a UtilityCost:Charge:Block?
output: The Source Variable is usually the name of the variable holding the energy or demand but may also be any variable including the subtotal or basis if other charges are based on those.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> Field: Season -> text
input: What does the Season field define?
output: The Season field defines the name or number of a season for which the UtilityCost:Charge:Block is calculated and if set to annual calculations are performed for the entire year.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> Field: Season -> text
input: What are the possible choices for the Season field?
output: The choices for the Season field include Annual Summer Winter Spring and Fall.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> Field: Category Variable Name -> text
input: What is the purpose of the Category Variable Name field?
output: The Category Variable Name field shows where the charge should be added in the hierarchy ensuring the charge is reported in a reasonable category.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> Field: Category Variable Name -> text
input: What are the choices for the Category Variable Name field?
output: The choices for the Category Variable Name field include EnergyCharges DemandCharges ServiceCharges Basis Adjustment Surcharge Subtotal Taxes Total and NotIncluded.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> Field: Remaining Into Variable -> text
input: What happens if the blocks do not use all of the energy or demand from the source?
output: If the blocks do not use all of the energy or demand the remaining amount should be assigned to a variable; otherwise a warning will be issued.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> Field: Block Size Multiplier Value or Variable Name -> text
input: What is the function of the Block Size Multiplier Value or Variable Name field?
output: The Block Size Multiplier Value or Variable Name field allows block sizes to be multiplied by an entered value or variable before use common in kWh/kW rates.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> Field: Block Size Multiplier Value or Variable Name -> text
input: What is assumed if no value is entered in the Block Size Multiplier Value or Variable Name field?
output: If no value is entered a default value of one is assumed so the block sizes remain exactly as entered.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: What are the choices for seasons in the EnergyPlus object?
output: The choices for seasons are: Annual Summer Winter Spring Fall.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: What does the 'Field: Category Variable Name' describe?
output: All charges get added somewhere in the hierarchy described in the introduction to EnergyPlus economics above. This field shows where the charge should be added.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: Why is it important to enter the 'Field: Category Variable Name' appropriately?
output: The reason to enter this field appropriately is so that the charge gets reported in a reasonable category.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: What happens automatically when a charge is added in the 'Field: Category Variable Name'?
output: The charge automatically gets added to the variable that is the category.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: What are the choices for the 'Field: Category Variable Name'?
output: The choices for this field are limited to: EnergyCharges DemandCharges ServiceCharges Basis Adjustment Surcharge Subtotal Taxes Total NotIncluded.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: What does the 'Field: Remaining Into Variable' specify?
output: If the blocks do not use all of the energy or demand from the source some energy and demand remains then the remaining amount should be assigned to a variable.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: What happens if no variable is assigned in the 'Field: Remaining Into Variable'?
output: If no variable is assigned and some amount of energy or demand is not used in the block structure a warning will be issued.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: What is the purpose of the 'Field: Block Size Multiplier Value or Variable Name'?
output: The sizes of the blocks are usually used directly but if a value or a variable is entered here the block sizes entered in the rest of the charge are first multiplied by the entered value prior to being used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: What is common for rates that are kWh/kW rates in the 'Field: Block Size Multiplier Value or Variable Name'?
output: In that case the variable that holds the monthly total electric demand would be entered.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: What is the default value if no value is entered in the 'Field: Block Size Multiplier Value or Variable Name'?
output: If no value is entered a default value of one is assumed so that the block sizes remain exactly as entered.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: Why is the 'Field: Block Size Multiplier Value or Variable Name' unusual for the EnergyPlus syntax?
output: This field is unusual for the EnergyPlus syntax because it can be either a number or a name of a variable.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: What is specified in the 'Field: Block Size 1 Value or Variable Name'?
output: The size of the first block of the charges is entered here.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: What is the default variable used for the remaining amount in the 'Field: Block Size 1 Value or Variable Name'?
output: A default variable named 'remaining' contains a large value and this may be used when the remaining amount should be included in that block.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: How can the 'Field: Block Size 1 Value or Variable Name' and the next field be repeated?
output: This field and the next field may be repeated in groups of two for as many blocks as are defined.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: Why is the 'Field: Block Size 1 Value or Variable Name' unusual for the EnergyPlus syntax?
output: This field is unusual for the EnergyPlus syntax because it can be either a number or a name of a variable.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: What does the 'Field: Block 1 Cost per Unit Value or Variable Name' specify?
output: The cost of the first block. This value is also repeated for every other field in the charge.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: How many blocks can be entered using the 'Field: Block 1 Cost per Unit Value or Variable Name'?
output: As many blocks may be entered as are needed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: How often can the 'Field: Block 1 Cost per Unit Value or Variable Name' and the previous field be repeated?
output: This field and the previous field may be repeated in groups of two for as many blocks as are defined.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: Why is the 'Field: Block 1 Cost per Unit Value or Variable Name' unusual for the EnergyPlus syntax?
output: This field is unusual for the EnergyPlus syntax because it can be either a number or a name of a variable.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: How are values usually expressed for SellToUtility tariffs in the 'Field: Block 1 Cost per Unit Value or Variable Name'?
output: For SellToUtility tariffs the values in this field are usually expressed as negative numbers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: How many times can the last two fields be repeated?
output: These last two fields may be repeated fifteen times.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Block -> text
input: What can be done if more blocks are defined by the utility?
output: The computation can be continued using another UtilityCost:Charge:Block and using the variable from Remaining Into Variable as the source variable.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Simple -> text
input: What is the UtilityCost:Charge:Simple object used for?
output: The UtilityCost:Charge:Simple is used for tariff calculation computing energy and demand charges taxes surcharges and other utility bill charges.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Simple -> text
input: How many UtilityCost:Charge:Simple objects can be defined for a single tariff?
output: As many UtilityCost:Charge:Simple objects as needed may be defined for a single tariff and they will be added together.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Simple -> text
input: What is the purpose of the 'Charge Variable Name' field?
output: The 'Charge Variable Name' field is associated with the UtilityCost:Charge:Simple object and appears in the report. It is also the name of the variable where the calculation results are stored.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Simple -> text
input: What happens to spaces in Charge Variable Names?
output: Spaces in Charge Variable Names are removed during the utility bill calculation process.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Simple -> text
input: What does the 'Tariff Name' field specify?
output: The 'Tariff Name' field specifies the name of the tariff associated with the UtilityCost:Charge:Simple.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Simple -> text
input: What is typically specified in the 'Source Variable' field?
output: The 'Source Variable' field typically specifies the name of the variable holding the energy or demand but it can also be the name of any variable including the subtotal or basis.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Simple -> text
input: What does the 'Season' field define?
output: The 'Season' field defines the name (or number) of a season for which the UtilityCost:Charge:Simple is calculated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Simple -> text
input: What happens if the 'Season' field is set to Annual?
output: If the 'Season' field is set to Annual calculations are performed for the entire year (all months).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Simple -> text
input: What are the choices for the 'Season' field?
output: The choices for the 'Season' field are Annual Winter Spring Summer and Fall.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Simple -> text
input: What does the 'Category Variable Name' field indicate?
output: The 'Category Variable Name' field indicates where the charge should be added in the hierarchy described in EnergyPlus economics.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Simple -> text
input: What are the options for the 'Category Variable Name' field?
output: The options for the 'Category Variable Name' field are EnergyCharges DemandCharges ServiceCharges Basis Adjustment Surcharge Subtotal Taxes Total and NotIncluded.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Simple -> text
input: What does the 'Cost per Unit Value or Variable Name' field contain?
output: The 'Cost per Unit Value or Variable Name' field contains either a single number or the name of a variable.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Simple -> text
input: What is the purpose of using a variable in the 'Cost per Unit Value or Variable Name' field?
output: Using a variable in the 'Cost per Unit Value or Variable Name' field allows monthly values of the variable to be multiplied against the source field variable.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Simple -> text
input: What assumption is made if no value or variable is entered in the 'Cost per Unit Value or Variable Name' field?
output: If no value or variable is entered a zero is assumed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Charge:Simple -> text
input: How are values usually expressed in the 'Cost per Unit Value or Variable Name' field for SellToUtility tariffs?
output: For SellToUtility tariffs values are usually expressed as negative numbers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Computation -> text
input: What is the purpose of the UtilityCost:Computation object?
output: The UtilityCost:Computation object lists a series of computations that are used to perform the bill calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Computation -> text
input: When should the UtilityCost:Computation object be used?
output: The object is only used for complex tariffs that cannot be modeled any other way.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Computation -> text
input: What percentage of utility tariffs do not require the use of UtilityCost:Computation?
output: For 95% of the utility tariffs using UtilityCost:Computation is unnecessary and should be avoided.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Computation -> text
input: What must the UtilityCost:Computation object contain if it is used?
output: If the UtilityCost:Computation object is used it must contain references to all objects involved in the rate in the order that they should be computed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What is described in the Inputs subsection?
output: The Inputs subsection describes the fields within the UtilityCost:Computation object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> Field: Name -> text
input: What does the 'Field: Name' represent?
output: The name of the UtilityCost:Computation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> Field: Tariff Name -> text
input: What does the 'Field: Tariff Name' indicate?
output: The name of the tariff that this UtilityCost:Charge:Simple is associated with.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> Field: Compute Step N -> text
input: What do the Compute Step fields contain?
output: The Compute Step fields contain a simple language that describes the steps used in the computation process similar to a programming language.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> Field: Compute Step N -> text
input: What happens if no entry is made to any Compute Step fields?
output: If no entry is made to any Compute Step fields a default method of computing the rates shall be used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> Field: Compute Step N -> text
input: Where is Compute Step described in detail?
output: Compute Step is described later in this section under Complex Tariff Modeling.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> Field: Compute Step N -> text
input: What is the general recommendation regarding the use of the UtilityCost:Computation object?
output: This object should be omitted for almost all tariffs.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: What do many utilities provide and how do they separate their customers?
output: Many utilities provide a large number of tariffs and separate their customers by the amount of energy use they have or by the amount of demand.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: What does the qualify object allow?
output: The qualify object allows only certain tariffs that are modeled to be used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: What happens if the results of the simulation fall outside of the range of qualifications?
output: If the results of the simulation fall outside of the range of qualifications that tariff is still calculated but the 'Qualified' entry will say 'No' and the UtilityCost:Qualify that caused its exclusion is shown.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: What should be ensured when multiple tariffs from the same utility are modeled?
output: When multiple tariffs from the same utility are modeled and only one of them should be used make sure that the qualifiers are consistent especially within the same GroupName.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: How many UtilityCost:Qualify objects can appear for a specific rate?
output: Multiple UtilityCost:Qualify objects can appear for a specific rate and they can be based on any variable.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: How does the energy used and demands vary for each month?
output: The energy used and demands for each month vary.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: What choice is necessary if energy use varies across the minimum and maximum values defined by this object?
output: A choice in how to treat the thresholds is necessary if energy use varies across the minimum and maximum values defined by this object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: What example is given for utility tariffs with demand requirements?
output: An example is given where a utility has two tariffs a small tariff with a maximum demand requirement of 50kW and a large tariff with a minimum demand requirement of 50kW.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: What might utilities have regarding months and thresholds for rate qualification?
output: Utilities probably have very specific requirements about which months or consecutive months can be above or below a threshold to qualify for the rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What is the purpose of the 'Field: Name' in UtilityCost:Qualify?
output: The 'Field: Name' is used for the UtilityCost:Qualify and displayed if the tariff does not qualify. It is also treated as a variable.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What values does the 'Field: Name' variable contain?
output: The 'Field: Name' variable contains: 1 for each month that does qualify 0 for months that do not qualify and -1 for months that are not part of the season selected.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What is the 'Field: Tariff Name' used for?
output: The 'Field: Tariff Name' is the name of the UtilityCost:Tariff object that is associated with this UtilityCost:Qualify object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What should be used for energy and demand in 'Field: Variable Name'?
output: For energy and demand the automatically created variables totalEnergy and totalDemand should be used respectively.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What options can be entered for 'Field: Qualify Type'?
output: For 'Field: Qualify Type' either 'Minimum' or 'Maximum' can be entered.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What does 'Field: Threshold Value or Variable Name' specify?
output: The 'Field: Threshold Value or Variable Name' specifies the minimum or maximum value for the qualify.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What happens if the variable values are less than the threshold when the qualify type is minimum?
output: If the variable has values that are less than this value when the qualify type is minimum then the tariff may be disqualified.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What happens if the variable values are greater than the threshold when the qualify type is maximum?
output: If the variable has values that are greater than this value when the qualify type is maximum then the tariff may be disqualified.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: How is the minimum demand defined in 'Field: Threshold Value or Variable Name'?
output: For demand it is still the minimum of the demands set each month even though the demands are by definition the peak value for the month.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What does the 'Field: Season' specify?
output: The 'Field: Season' specifies if the UtilityCost:Qualify only applies to a season and the season name can be chosen from Annual Winter Spring Summer or Fall.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What happens if the 'Field: Season' is left blank?
output: If the 'Field: Season' is left blank it defaults to Annual.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What options can be entered for 'Field: Threshold Test'?
output: For 'Field: Threshold Test' either 'Count' or 'Consecutive' can be entered.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What does the 'Field: Threshold Test' determine?
output: The 'Field: Threshold Test' determines how the number in Number of Months is used either as a count of total months per year or based on consecutive months.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What is the default setting for 'Field: Threshold Test' if left blank?
output: If left blank the 'Field: Threshold Test' defaults to 'count'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What does the 'Field: Number of Months' specify?
output: The 'Field: Number of Months' specifies a number from 1 to 12 and if no value is entered 12 is assumed when the qualify type is minimum.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: What is the purpose of the UtilityCost:Qualify object?
output: The UtilityCost:Qualify object is associated with a specific object to determine if a tariff qualifies based on certain criteria.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: What is specified in the 'Field: Variable Name' for UtilityCost:Qualify?
output: The name of the variable used is specified and for energy and demand the automatically created variables totalEnergy and totalDemand should be used respectively.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: What options can be entered in the 'Field: Qualify Type'?
output: Either 'Minimum' or 'Maximum' can be entered in the 'Field: Qualify Type'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: What does the 'Field: Threshold Value or Variable Name' specify?
output: It specifies the minimum or maximum value for the qualify. If the variable has values that are less than this value when the qualify type is minimum the tariff may be disqualified. If the variable has values that are greater than this value when the qualify type is maximum the tariff may be disqualified.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: How does the 'Field: Threshold Value or Variable Name' affect demand qualification?
output: For demand it is still the minimum of the demands set each month even though the demands are by definition the peak value for the month. Depending on the threshold test entry this minimum applies to all months some of the months or just a single month.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: What should be entered in the 'Field: Season'?
output: If the UtilityCost:Qualify only applies to a season enter the season name from the following list: Annual Winter Spring Summer Fall. If this field is left blank it defaults to Annual.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: What options are available for the 'Field: Threshold Test'?
output: Enter either 'Count' or 'Consecutive'. If left blank this field defaults to count and it should be allowed to default for most cases.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: How does the 'Field: Threshold Test' utilize the 'Number of Months'?
output: If the Threshold Test is set to 'Count' the qualification is based on the count of the total number of months per year. If set to 'Consecutive' the qualification is based on a consecutive number of months.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: What is specified in the 'Field: Number of Months'?
output: A number from 1 to 12. If no value is entered 12 is assumed when the qualify type is minimum and 1 when the qualify type is maximum.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Qualify -> text
input: How is the 'Field: Number of Months' affected if the season is less than 12 months?
output: If the season is less than 12 months (if it is not annual) then the value is automatically reduced to the number of months of the season.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What does the UtilityCost:Ratchet command allow?
output: The UtilityCost:Ratchet command allows the modeling of tariffs that include some type of seasonal ratcheting.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: When are ratchets most commonly used?
output: Ratchets are most common when used with electric demand charges.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What is a ratchet in terms of utility demand charges?
output: A ratchet is when a utility requires that the demand charge for a month with a low demand may be increased to be more consistent with a month that set a higher demand charge.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: How is an example useful in understanding the UtilityCost:Ratchet command?
output: An example is probably the easiest way to learn the basic functions of the UtilityCost:Ratchet command.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What does the ratchet example illustrate regarding utility billing demand?
output: The ratchet example illustrates that a utility has a single ratchet that says the billing demand for each month of the year is the higher value of the actual demand or 60% of the peak summer demand.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> listing
input: What is the content of the ratchet example listing?
output: UtilityCost:Ratchet BillingDemand1 ExampleTariff1 TotalDemand TotalDemand Summer Annual 0.60 0;

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: Where should the Ratchet Variable Name be used?
output: The Ratchet Variable Name should be used wherever the ratchet should be applied and is often the source variable for UtilityCost:Charge:Simple or UtilityCost:Charge:Block.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What are the detailed steps taken for the ratchet?
output: The detailed steps taken for the ratchet are described in a list format detailing how AdjSeasonal AdjPeak MaxAdjBase and the resulting Ratchet Variable are calculated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> item
input: What does AdjSeasonal contain?
output: AdjSeasonal contains either the maximum for all months in Season From in the Adjustment Source Variable if SeasonFrom is not set to Monthly or the monthly values of the Adjustment Source Variable if SeasonFrom is set to Monthly.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> equation
input: How is AdjPeak calculated?
output: AdjPeak = (AdjSeasonal + Offset) * Multiplier

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> equation
input: How is MaxAdjBase determined?
output: MaxAdjBase = maximum value of either AdjPeak or Baseline Source Variable

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> item
input: What does the resulting Ratchet Variable contain for months not in SeasonTo?
output: For months not in SeasonTo the Ratchet Variable contains the values of Baseline Source Variable.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> item
input: What does the resulting Ratchet Variable contain for months in SeasonTo?
output: For months in SeasonTo the Ratchet Variable contains the values of MaxAdjBase.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: How should multiple ratchets be handled in the same tariff?
output: Multiple UtilityCost:Ratchet commands should be chained together with the Baseline Source Variable of subsequent ratchets referencing the Ratchet Variable Name of the previous UtilityCost:Ratchet.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What operations can the ratchet command perform?
output: The ratchet command can add together two variables multiply two variables or take the maximum value between two variables.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: Why should clever use of UtilityCost:Ratchet be documented?
output: Clever use of UtilityCost:Ratchet should be well documented with comments to ensure clarity and proper understanding.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What is described in the Inputs subsection?
output: The Inputs subsection describes various fields and their meanings such as Ratchet Variable Name Tariff Name Baseline Source Variable and others.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> paragraph
input: What is the Field: Ratchet Variable Name?
output: The Field: Ratchet Variable Name is the name of the ratchet and the name of the result of this single ratchet.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> paragraph
input: What is the Field: Tariff Name?
output: The Field: Tariff Name is the name of the tariff that this UtilityCost:Ratchet is associated with.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> paragraph
input: What is the Field: Baseline Source Variable?
output: The Field: Baseline Source Variable is the name of the variable used as the baseline value. When the ratcheted value exceeds the baseline value for a month the ratcheted value is used but when the baseline value is greater the baseline value is used. Usually the electric demand charge is used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> paragraph
input: What is the Field: Adjustment Source Variable?
output: The Field: Adjustment Source Variable is the variable that the ratchet is calculated from. It is often but not always the same as the baseline source variable. The ratcheting calculations using offset and multiplier are using the values from the adjustment source variable.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> paragraph
input: What is the Field: Season From?
output: The Field: Season From is the name of the season that is being examined. The maximum value for all of the months in the named season is what is used with the multiplier.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What should be done if multiple ratchets occur in the same tariff?
output: Multiple UtilityCost:Ratchet commands should be chained together with the Baseline Source Variable with subsequent ratchets referencing the Ratchet Variable Name of the previous UtilityCost:Ratchet.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: How can the ratchet command be used for difficult to model tariffs?
output: The ratchet command can add together two variables multiply two variables or take the maximum value between two variables making it useful for other difficult to model tariffs without needing to use UtilityCost:Computation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What should be done with the clever use of UtilityCost:Ratchet?
output: Clever use of UtilityCost:Ratchet should be well documented with comments.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What is the purpose of the Ratchet Variable Name field?
output: The Ratchet Variable Name field specifies the name of the ratchet and the name of the result of this single ratchet.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What does the Tariff Name field represent?
output: The Tariff Name field represents the name of the tariff that this UtilityCost:Ratchet is associated with.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What is the Baseline Source Variable?
output: The Baseline Source Variable is the name of the variable used as the baseline value. When the ratcheted value exceeds the baseline value for a month the ratcheted value is used but when the baseline value is greater than the ratcheted value the baseline value is used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: Can the Baseline Source Variable be the result of another ratchet object?
output: Yes the Baseline Source Variable can be the result of another ratchet object allowing utility tariffs with multiple ratchets to be modeled.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What is the Adjustment Source Variable?
output: The Adjustment Source Variable is the variable from which the ratchet is calculated. It is often but not always the same as the baseline source variable.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What happens if the Adjustment Source Variable is left blank?
output: If the Adjustment Source Variable is left blank it is the same as the baseline source variable.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What is the purpose of the Season From field?
output: The Season From field specifies the name of the season that is being examined. The maximum value for all months in the named season is used with the multiplier and offset.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What are the common values for the Season From field?
output: The common values for the Season From field are Annual Winter Spring Summer Fall and Monthly.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What is the purpose of the Season To field?
output: The Season To field specifies the name of the season when the ratchet would be calculated and the ratchet is only applied to the months in the named season.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What are the common values for the Season To field?
output: The common values for the Season To field are Annual Winter Spring Summer and Fall.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What is the Multiplier Value or Variable Name field used for?
output: The Multiplier Value or Variable Name field is used for entering a multiplier such as 0.9 for a clause like 'the current month demand or 90% of the summer month demand'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What is the default value if no multiplier is needed?
output: If no multiplier is needed the default value is one.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What is the Offset Value or Variable Name field used for?
output: The Offset Value or Variable Name field is used for entering an offset that is added to the demand often negative to represent a reduction in demand.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Ratchet -> text
input: What is assumed if no offset value is entered?
output: If no offset value is entered it is assumed to be zero and does not affect the ratchet.

output: Effectively the rate charge for purchased electricity is the same as the rate credited for electricity sold to the utility.

input: What should the 'Buy or Sell' field be set to in net metering?
output: In this the 'Buy or Sell' field should be set to 'netMetering'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff Examples -> text
input: What is important about the 'Output Meter' in net metering?
output: It is also important the 'Output Meter' is set to a meter that represents net metering such as 'ElectricityNet:Facility'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff Examples -> text
input: What does the following example show?
output: The following example shows a simple example tariff using net metering with a single UtilityCost:Charge:Simple.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff Examples -> listing
input: What is the listing for the UtilityCost:Tariff example using net metering?
output: UtilityCost:Tariff ExampleI-NetMeter ElectricityNet:Facility kWh      30.00     netMetering;

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff Examples -> listing
input: What is the listing for the UtilityCost:Charge:Simple example using net metering?
output: UtilityCost:Charge:Simple NetMeteredCharge ExampleI-NetMeter totalEnergy Annual EnergyCharges 0.065;

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff Reporting -> text
input: What is created to show all components of all categories in the calculation sequence?
output: A standardized tabular output report is created which shows all components of all categories in the calculation sequence on a variable basis (usually 12 numbers one for each month).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff Reporting -> text
input: How can the economics reports be requested?
output: The economics reports may be requested by specifying TariffReport and EconomicResultSummary in the Output:Table:SummaryReports object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff Reporting -> text
input: When are the economics reports generated?
output: They are also generated with any of the AllSummary options.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff Reporting -> text
input: In what units are the values reported?
output: The values reported are in the units specified in the UtilityCost:Tariff object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What does the UtilityCost:Tariff section define?
output: It defines the name of the tariff the type of tariff and other details about the overall tariff.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: Which objects reference the tariff name in the UtilityCost:Tariff model?
output: The objects include UtilityCost:Charge:Simple UtilityCost:Charge:Block UtilityCost:Ratchet UtilityCost:Qualify UtilityCost:Variable and UtilityCost:Computation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: Can multiple UtilityCost:Tariff objects appear in the same IDF file?
output: Yes multiple UtilityCost:Tariff objects can appear in the same IDF file.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: Why might there be more than one rate used by electric and gas utilities?
output: Because it is common for electric and gas utilities to have more than one rate that may be used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: How is the UtilityCost:Tariff chosen for the Economics Summary Report?
output: Only one UtilityCost:Tariff for each Output:Meter object and Group Name is shown in the Economics Summary Report. It is chosen by first eliminating UtilityCost:Tariff objects that are not qualified due to their UtilityCost:Qualify objects. If more than one remains the one with the lowest cost for a combination of a Meter and Group Name is selected.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What happens if the Group Name field is not used when selecting a UtilityCost:Tariff?
output: If the Group Name field is not used the lowest cost UtilityCost:Tariff is chosen for each Meter.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What is part of the tariff description used for?
output: It is used to transform the annual energy use of any fuel under any meter into a group of named variables containing the values for each of the periods that the bills are calculated (usually monthly).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What variables are created by the schedules in the UtilityCost:Tariff?
output: The schedules create a variable for energy use and for demand. If specified it also creates a variable for energy and a variable for demand for the 'on-peak' 'off-peak' and 'shoulder' periods for use in time-of-use tariffs.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What variables are always created in the UtilityCost:Tariff?
output: The variables that are always created are totalEnergy and totalDemand.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What is the field 'Name' used for in the UtilityCost:Tariff?
output: The name of the tariff. Tariffs are sometimes called rates. The name is used in identifying the output results and in associating all of the charges and other objects that make up a tariff.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What is the 'Output Meter Name' field in the UtilityCost:Tariff?
output: The name of any meter defined but usually set to either Electricity:Facility or NaturalGas:Facility.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What does the 'Conversion Factor Choice' field allow in the UtilityCost:Tariff?
output: A choice that allows several different predefined conversion factors to be used; otherwise user-defined conversion factors are used as defined in the next two fields.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What are some of the predefined conversion factors available in the UtilityCost:Tariff?
output: UserDefined kWh Therm MMBtu MJ KBtu MCF CCF m3 gal kgal.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: Will all conversion factor choices be accepted by EnergyPlus?
output: Not all choices will be accepted by EnergyPlus depending on the resource of the Output Meter of the tariff object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: How does EnergyPlus differentiate between meters?
output: EnergyPlus will differentiate between Water Meters and Energy Meters. Energy Meters natively report energy in Joules (J) and demand in Joules/Sec (J/s) which is equivalent to Watts (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What happens if the Conversion Factor Choice is omitted or invalid?
output: The default is kWh and a warning is issued to the user.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: How does EnergyPlus determine accepted options for conversion factors?
output: EnergyPlus will make a distinction between Electric Gas and Other meters to determine the accepted options.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Chapter: EnergyPlus Economics -> Section: Inputs -> text
input: What warning is issued if Therm is used for an electric meter?
output: The user is warned that this is an unusual choice for electricity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What is the name of the tariff used for?
output: The name of the tariff is used in identifying the output results and in associating all of the charges and other objects that make up a tariff.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What is the usual setting for the Output Meter Name?
output: The name of any meter defined but usually set to either Electricity:Facility or NaturalGas:Facility.

output: The Conversion Factor Choice field allows several different predefined conversion factors to be used; otherwise user-defined conversion factors are used as defined in the next two fields.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text

output: The name of a schedule that defines the seasons.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What are the values for the different seasons?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: When must the change in the season schedule occur?
output: The change in the season schedule must occur at the same time as the change in the Monthly Schedule.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What variables are automatically created if a season schedule is used?
output: Variables such as isWinter isNotWinter isSpring isNotSpring isSummer isNotSummer isAutumn isNotAutumn are created.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What is the purpose of the Month Schedule Name field?
output: The name of the schedule that defines the billing periods of the year.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What is the default behavior for the Month Schedule?
output: Normally this entry is allowed to default and a schedule will be internally used with breaks between billing periods occurring at the same time as the breaks between months.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What should be ensured when using month and season schedules?
output: Make sure that the month schedule and season schedule are consistent otherwise an error will be issued.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What are the values for the months in the Month Schedule?
output: 1 is January 2 is February 3 is March 4 is April 5 is May 6 is June 7 is July 8 is August 9 is September 10 is October 11 is November 12 is December.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: When must a season schedule occur in relation to a Monthly Schedule?
output: A season schedule must occur at the same time as the change in the Monthly Schedule.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What happens if a season schedule is used?
output: Variables are automatically created if a season schedule is used. These variables are set to 1 within the season and 0 for the months that are not in the season.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What are the variables created when a season schedule is used?
output: The variables are: isWinter isNotWinter isSpring isNotSpring isSummer isNotSummer isAutumn isNotAutumn.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What is the purpose of the 'Month Schedule Name' field?
output: The 'Month Schedule Name' field defines the billing periods of the year.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What happens if no schedule is specified for the month schedule?
output: If no schedule is specified a default Month Schedule is used which defines the months of the year as the normal calendar months.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What are some examples of billing periods other than monthly?
output: Examples include two-month cycles or a single bill for an entire season such as some natural gas companies do in the summer.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What must be consistent to avoid errors in monthly and season schedules?
output: The month schedule and season schedule must be consistent otherwise an error will be issued.

output: 1 is the first month usually January.

output: 3 is the third month usually March.

output: 4 is the fourth month usually April.

output: 5 is the fifth month usually May.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Economics -> Section: UtilityCost:Tariff -> text
input: What number corresponds to June in the month schedule?
output: 6 is the sixth month usually June.
